reinforcements.similarity: Both address the human-to-digital trust handoff -- bridging the agent's trust to the platform through continuity signals. The new element prescribes that platform triggers inherit the agent's identity (emails from Bryant, not noreply@splitlease.com; first screen shows Bryant's name and the host's data). The existing element prescribes continuity priming during the call and platform-side echoing of the call conversation.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Existing evidence (andreas-call.txt): the call ends with human-to-human promises, the platform is never mentioned, and the host's first encounter is unprimed. New evidence (june-call.txt, 13:27): Bryant promises 'I'll get those listings created. I can send you an email with a link.' June is depleted ('going through a lot of stuff,' 06:33) and time-constrained ('a couple of zoom calls today,' 00:19). Combined: both hosts (Andreas and June) end the call expecting to deal with Bryant, not a platform. June's case adds the depleted-user dimension -- she has even less tolerance for a trust reset than Andreas. Saffer's trigger consistency principle (Ch. 2, p. 26) reinforces Kahneman's priming from the existing element: recognized triggers must initiate the same action every time, and June's recognized trigger is Bryant.

reinforcements.similarity: Both prescribe that every screen opens with what the host already knows before demanding new input. The existing element establishes 'Anchor-Then-Advance' (show host's own data first, then context, then new fields). The new element architects a 'Persistent Rule Verification Strip' that displays host-defined rules (rent, deposit, cleaning fee, utility cap) as always-visible reference information on every decision screen.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Existing evidence (andreas-call.txt): Andreas describes units fluently from known information; the platform should present this data back as an anchor. New evidence (june-call.txt, 07:32 and 10:59): June asked the identical fee question twice in one call, proving one-time verbal feedback does not persist. Saffer Ch. 4, p. 86: 'Feedback Illuminates the Rules.' The combined insight elevates anchor-then-advance from a screen-opening principle to a persistent-visibility principle: it is not enough to lead with the host's data -- that data must remain visible at all times. June's repeated question is the empirical proof that anchoring works only when it is permanent, not just initial.

reinforcements.similarity: Both address the agent continuity frame on the platform. The existing element prescribes that the platform attributes its communications to the agent (Bryant's name and photo in the header, agent-attributed messages). The new element architects a specific first-screen design: headline 'Bryant prepared your listing,' property address, pricing summary, and a single 'Review and Confirm' action.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Existing evidence (andreas-call.txt, 5:27-6:11): call ends with personal commitments from Bryant, no platform mentioned. New evidence (june-call.txt, 13:27): 'I'll get those listings created. I can send you an email with a link.' Both calls establish the same agent-first expectation. The new element adds specificity that the existing element lacks: the exact screen layout for the first visit (agent-attributed headline, pre-populated data, review-not-create framing). June's depleted state (06:33) adds urgency: the first screen must eliminate orientation cost entirely. Saffer's Don't Start from Zero (Ch. 3, p. 64) provides the microinteractions framework for the existing Kahneman priming principle.

reinforcements.similarity: Both address the gap between the host's mental model and the platform's data model. The existing element focuses on vocabulary and format translation (monthly rent vs. nightly rate, natural language vs. dropdowns). The new element focuses on capturing conditional, parameterized rules that go beyond binary toggles (utility cap at $40 with guest-paid overage, not just 'utilities included: yes/no').
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Existing evidence (andreas-call.txt, 3:02-3:16): Andreas thinks in monthly rent and sequential sums. The platform must accept input in his native format. New evidence (june-call.txt, 04:08-04:51): June has a $40 utility cap with conditional overage assignment -- a parameterized rule that cannot be captured by a simple toggle. Saffer Ch. 3, p. 52-64: 'Rules define the hidden parameters.' The combined insight extends the mental-model translation principle from vocabulary/format to rule structure: the platform must not only accept the host's words and numbers but also their conditional logic. June's case adds a new category of translation -- from conditional verbal rules to structured platform rules.

reinforcements.similarity: Both address proposal presentation as a confirmation task, not a construction task. The existing element prescribes pre-packaged proposals (tenant narrative first, matched terms second, single confirm action third). The new element architects a single-surface proposal screen with three zones (Guest, Terms, Action) visible without scrolling, including inline vetting badges, rule-match indicators, and cross-platform calendar impact.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Existing evidence (andreas-call.txt, 1:58-2:19): Bryant presents tenants as a pre-packaged deal. New evidence (june-call.txt, 05:40-05:52 and 06:04-06:15): June demands speed ('decide quickly because I have to block other platforms') AND thoroughness ('I need to know who they are'). The combined insight adds the cross-platform dimension and the speed-thoroughness tension that the existing element does not address. Saffer's visual feedback principle (Ch. 4, p. 96) provides the mechanism: badges and checkmarks enable simultaneous verification that resolves the speed-thoroughness tension.

reinforcements.similarity: Both address how the platform notifies and updates the host during the active lease. The existing element prescribes notifications as continuations of the agent's conversation. The new element prescribes an ambient-to-alert lease health escalation loop with adaptive feedback frequency (frequent early, ambient later; green for compliance, amber/red for issues).
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Existing evidence (andreas-call.txt): the call establishes agent-mediated communication; notifications should carry agent identity. New evidence (june-call.txt, 04:26-04:51): June's utility abuse trauma demands continuous monitoring confirmation, not just agent-attributed messages. Saffer's Long Loop principle (Ch. 5, p. 117) adds the temporal dimension: notifications must evolve over the lease term. The combined insight is that notifications must be both agent-attributed (existing) AND adaptive in frequency and urgency (new).

reinforcements.similarity: Both address multi-unit hosts who need batch operations. The existing element prescribes multi-unit batch operations (duplicate, modify, manage together) at the interaction level. The new element prescribes building-level attribute inheritance (address, utility policy, deposit set once, inherited by all units) with per-unit override capability.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Existing evidence (andreas-call.txt, 1:03-1:10): Andreas has two units he describes as variations of each other. New evidence (june-call.txt, 09:36-09:41): June proactively offers to list both apartments and has a building-level utility rule ($40 cap) that applies to all units. Saffer Ch. 3, p. 69: Limited Options and Smart Defaults -- the second listing should inherit from the first. The combined insight adds the building-vs-unit tier distinction that the existing batch operations element lacks. June's utility cap proves the need for shared building-level rules, not just duplicated unit-level data.

reinforcements.similarity: Both address the first platform impression and the need for cognitive ease and familiarity. The existing element prescribes cognitive ease as the foundation of trust (the first 2 seconds set everything). The new element prescribes 'recognition before demand' -- the host must feel known before being asked to do anything, with the specific emotional target of relief.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Existing evidence (Kahneman's cognitive ease research): familiar stimuli generate positive affect automatically. New evidence (june-call.txt, 06:33 and 13:27): June is depleted and expects Bryant to have done the work. The combined insight adds the depletion dimension: cognitive ease matters even more when the user arrives depleted. The target emotion shifts from generic 'ease' to specific 'relief' -- the feeling that the promise was kept.

reinforcements.similarity: Both address the emotional arc around guaranteed income. The existing element prescribes showing the money first, then showing why it is safe (tension-relief arc). The new element prescribes earned trust through recurring proof (payment confirmations each cycle, not silence).
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Existing evidence: the initial tension-relief arc at the moment the guarantee is first communicated. New evidence (june-call.txt, 02:53-03:25 and 04:26-04:51): the guarantee promise must be reinforced each payment cycle because June has been burned before. Silence is not reassurance for a host with negative past experiences. Saffer's Long Loop principle extends the tension-relief arc from a single moment to a recurring confirmation loop. The combined insight: the guarantee's emotional impact is not a one-time event but a monthly reinforcement that accumulates into trust.

reinforcements.similarity: Both address trust-signaling visual elements. The existing element prescribes green trust badges using the accent color exclusively for verified and guaranteed elements. The new element designs two specific badge patterns: a vetting badge (accent-green, checkmark, 'Vetted by Split Lease' in mono) and a payment guarantee badge (signal-info-blue, shield, 'Payment Guaranteed' in mono).
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Existing evidence: accent-green is reserved for trust signals to create a learned association. New evidence: June demands visible proof of both vetting ('I need to know who they are,' 06:04) and payment guarantee (02:53-03:25). Saffer Ch. 4, p. 96: visual feedback is the most effective form. The combined insight specifies two distinct badge types within the existing green-trust framework and adds a blue badge variant for the payment guarantee, extending the visual trust language.

contradictions.conflict: The existing element prescribes progressive disclosure through visual weight (dense content fades, not hides) as a universal principle. The new element's building-vs-unit two-tier visual hierarchy uses ink-muted (#8a857e) on bg-deep (#eae7e1) for the building banner, yielding approximately 2.7:1 contrast -- below WCAG AA for body text. The new element acknowledges this and compensates with larger text, but this creates tension with the library's baseline accessibility commitment.
contradictions.evidence_comparison: The existing element's principle (fade, not hide) is sound but does not specifically address the multi-unit context where confirmed data must be visually secondary to editable data. The new element's evidence is stronger for the specific use case (June's two-unit listing, Saffer's Don't Start from Zero) but the contrast solution (16px bold or larger) adds a new constraint. Both have merit; the resolution is to update the progressive disclosure principle to include a minimum contrast floor for faded content.
contradictions.recommendation: Adopt the new element's two-tier visual system but enforce a minimum of 3:1 contrast for all text, even in the confirmed/muted state. This may require using ink-soft (#4a4640) instead of ink-muted (#8a857e) for building banner values, yielding approximately 4.3:1 contrast on bg-deep. Flag for design review.

extensions.gap_filled: Cross-platform complexity absorption. No existing library element addresses the multi-platform host's operational burden (calendar blocking across Furnished Finder and other platforms, data import from existing listings, double-booking prevention). This is a new category of process pattern that extends beyond the platform's own boundaries.
extensions.confidence_note: Single-lens evidence from one host (June), but the pattern is structurally sound: any host operating on multiple platforms faces this coordination burden. The Saffer 'Absorb Complexity' principle (Ch. 3, p. 67) provides strong theoretical backing. Medium-high confidence as a real pattern, but needs validation with additional multi-platform hosts.

extensions.gap_filled: Active lease monitoring as an adaptive long loop. No existing library element addresses the active lease phase with ongoing utility monitoring, payment confirmation, and roommate replacement events. The existing library is strong on the pre-lease journey (discovery through proposal) but thin on what happens during the lease itself.
extensions.confidence_note: Single-lens evidence, but June's utility abuse story (04:26-04:51) is emotionally charged and behaviorally specific. Saffer's Long Loops and Spring-Loaded Modes principles (Ch. 5) provide strong structural framework. High confidence that active lease monitoring is a real gap; the specific adaptive frequency curve (more frequent early, ambient later) needs validation.

extensions.gap_filled: Single-surface proposal review with all host rules verified at glance. The existing library element communicates-005 prescribes pre-packaged proposals, but does not architect the specific verification surface (vetting badge, rule-match indicators, cross-platform calendar impact, payment guarantee badge all on one screen). This element fills the gap between the conceptual proposal pattern and its physical implementation.
extensions.confidence_note: Single-lens evidence, but combines June's explicit demands (speed + thoroughness) with Saffer's visual feedback hierarchy. The cross-platform calendar impact disclosure is unique to this lens and extends the existing proposal architecture significantly.

extensions.gap_filled: Cross-platform calendar impact disclosure at commitment points. No existing library element acknowledges that accepting a Split Lease booking has consequences on other platforms. This panel sits between terms verification and the action button on proposal screens, surfacing the dates and platform names the host needs to block elsewhere.
extensions.confidence_note: Single-lens evidence from June (05:40-05:52), but the pattern is inherent to any multi-platform host. Saffer's Absorb Complexity principle provides theoretical support. The element is well-scoped as a disclosure panel that does not require full calendar sync automation to deliver value.

extensions.gap_filled: Adaptive lease health dashboard with ambient-to-alert escalation. No existing library element provides an information architecture for the active lease monitoring experience. The ambient-vs-alert mode system with adaptive feedback density fills a significant gap in the coverage map for the active_lease phase.
extensions.confidence_note: Single-lens evidence, but Saffer's Long Loops and Modes framework provides robust structural guidance. The three-status-row design (payment, utility, timeline) maps directly to June's stated concerns. Moderate confidence -- needs validation with hosts who have different active-lease anxieties (e.g., property damage rather than utility abuse).

extensions.gap_filled: Ambient-to-alert color escalation system for long-running dashboards. The existing library addresses color use for trust signals (green badges) and financial displays, but has no pattern for color-as-state-communication over time. The three-tier green/amber/red system with 200ms transitions fills this gap.
extensions.confidence_note: Single-lens evidence, but the green/amber/red color convention is well-established in interaction design. The token system already includes signal-warn and signal-danger colors. Saffer's spring-loaded mode principle validates the behavioral model. High confidence in the pattern; the specific transition timing (200ms) needs usability testing.

extensions.gap_filled: Protection-rule visual emphasis. No existing element distinguishes between ordinary data fields and protection-driven host rules (rules born from painful experiences). The left-border accent treatment creates a visual signature that follows protection rules across all journey phases, signaling 'this boundary is respected.'
extensions.confidence_note: Single-lens evidence from June's utility cap and vetting stories, but the distinction between preferences and protections is psychologically meaningful and likely applies to other hosts with negative rental experiences. Medium confidence as a visual pattern; needs validation that hosts perceive and value the visual distinction.

extensions.gap_filled: Protective confidence through visible rule enforcement. No existing element addresses the emotional lifecycle of protection rules: captured during listing, applied during proposal, enforced during lease. The existing library has 'relief of guaranteed income' but not the ongoing enforcement narrative that builds trust for experience-scarred hosts.
extensions.confidence_note: Single-lens evidence, but the emotional logic is compelling: a host who set rules because of past harm needs to see those rules enforced, not just recorded. The pattern extends across multiple journey phases, giving it structural robustness despite single-lens origin.

extensions.gap_filled: Vigilance offloading during active lease. No existing element addresses the progressive transfer of monitoring burden from the host to the platform. The emotional arc (from 'I need to check' to 'I trust they will tell me') is a new emotional design pattern for long-running relationships.

Medium confidence -- the progressive notification reduction needs careful calibration to avoid hosts feeling abandoned.

extensions.confidence_note: Single-lens evidence, but the enforcement lifecycle concept is architecturally necessary: a rule without enforcement feedback is functionally invisible. The element connects L1 (process), L2 (information), L3 (visual), and L4 (behavioral) layers, which is a strong structural signal.

The core token system (colors, typography, spacing, radius, easing, shadows) is not affected. All five new tokens are small, well-scoped additions that do not conflict with existing values. The progress-bar-radius can reuse the existing 'full: 9999px' radius token rather than creating a duplicate.

journey_emotion_map.notes: June was surprised she hadn't heard of Split Lease (07:47). Existing library targets cognitive ease at discovery. This lens adds: the discovery trigger must work even for hosts who manage their own pipeline.

June evaluates through the lens of self-protection (fees? vetting? calendar impact?). The existing library targets trust through process-before-promise. This lens adds: protection-driven evaluation is a distinct emotional mode for experienced landlords.

June expects Bryant to handle everything. feels-001 targets relief. The existing library targets cognitive ease. Alignment is strong -- both converge on 'the host should feel the work was done for them.'

June expects to review, not create. feels-005 targets momentum and professional respect. The existing library targets conversational speed. This lens adds: multi-property hosts need the platform to treat them as portfolio managers, not beginners.

June's pricing is non-negotiable and includes a conditional utility rule. feels-006 targets calm through persistent certainty. The existing library targets single-sum clarity. This lens adds: the utility cap is a protection mechanism, not a pricing preference.

June needs speed AND thoroughness. feels-004 targets confidence through completeness. The existing library targets confirmation-not-construction. Alignment is strong with an important addition: cross-platform calendar pressure adds urgency the existing library does not address.

June's utility abuse history creates hypervigilance. feels-007 targets vigilance offloading. feels-002 targets safety through visible enforcement. feels-003 targets confidence through recurring proof. This is the phase where this lens contributes the most new emotional content.
June proactively offers to expand (list second apartment). feels-005 targets professional momentum. The existing library targets forward momentum. Alignment is strong.

arc_conflicts: Potential tension between 'urgency' at proposal_mgmt and 'calm' at active_lease. The emotional design must make a clear transition from the time-pressured proposal decision to the ambient monitoring of the active lease. The transition point is the acceptance confirmation, which should include a decompression signal (calendar panel reminder, then the green dashboard).

The 'professional respect' emotion in listing_creation could conflict with 'recognition before demand' in onboarding for the same host if she is multi-tasking between reviewing Bryant's prepared listing and creating a second listing. The second listing flow (building inheritance) must maintain the professional respect tone, not revert to the 'we did it for you' tone of the first listing review.
emotional_arc_check.arc_assessment: The emotional arc is coherent end-to-end: it moves from surprise/openness (discovery) through cautious self-protection (evaluation) to delegated relief (onboarding) to professional confirmation (listing/pricing) to equipped decisiveness (proposal) to calm vigilance-offloading (active lease) to expansion momentum (retention). The primary contribution of this lens is the active_lease emotional architecture (calm, safety, offloaded vigilance), which was the weakest phase in the existing library's emotional coverage. The arc makes emotional sense because it progressively transfers burden from the host to the platform -- and the host can verify this transfer at each step.

discovery.notes: New elements works-002 and communicates-003 touch discovery (agent trust inheritance, first screen). Existing library is also thin here. Discovery remains the weakest phase across the library.

evaluation.notes: New elements works-001 (hidden rules), works-006 (single-surface proposal verification), looks-003 (trust badges), feels-004 (equipped urgency). Evaluation coverage is growing with each lens.

onboarding.notes: New elements works-002 (agent trust), communicates-003 (entry screen), looks-002 (warm personalization), behaves-001 (optimistic listing confirmation), feels-001 (recognition before demand). Strong coverage of the human-to-digital handoff.

listing_creation.notes: Heaviest coverage in this run: rule capture, multi-unit architecture, building inheritance, persistent rule strip, two-tier visual hierarchy, optimistic confirmation, multi-unit duplication, professional respect. Listing creation is now the best-covered phase in the library.

pricing.notes: New elements works-001 (conditional utility rules), works-004 (multi-property pricing inheritance), communicates-006 (building-level pricing), feels-006 (persistent certainty). Pricing coverage extends the existing library's single-sum principle with conditional rule capture.

proposal_mgmt.notes: New elements works-006 (single-surface review), communicates-002 (decision screen), communicates-004 (calendar impact), looks-003 (trust badges), looks-005 (calendar panel), behaves-003 (inline verification), feels-004 (equipped urgency). Proposal management is now comprehensively covered.

active_lease.notes: This lens fills the library's biggest gap. New elements works-001 (rule enforcement), works-005 (adaptive long loop), communicates-005 (health dashboard), looks-004 (ambient-to-alert color), behaves-004 (escalation loop), behaves-007 (enforcement confirmation), feels-002 (protective confidence), feels-003 (earned trust), feels-007 (vigilance offloading). Active lease was previously 'none'; now 'strong'.

retention.notes: New elements works-003 (cross-platform complexity), works-004 (multi-property defaults), looks-006 (two-tier visual), feels-005 (professional momentum). Retention coverage grows but still depends on the first lease going well -- no retention-recovery elements yet.

loop_back_recommendations.reason: The existing works-006 (mental model translation) should be re-examined with the Microinteractions lens to add conditional rule capture as a distinct translation category.
loop_back_recommendations.new_input: Saffer's 'Designing Rules' framework (Ch. 3, p. 52-64) provides a structural model for parameterized host rules. The utility cap example ($40 threshold with conditional overage assignment) is the prototype. Re-examine works-006 to add: (1) conditional rules with thresholds and assignments, (2) temporal rules with start/end dates, (3) building-level vs. unit-level rule scoping.

loop_back_recommendations.reason: The new protection-rule visual emphasis (looks-007, left-border accent) should be reconciled with the existing progressive disclosure principle (looks-006) to establish a unified contrast floor for the muted/confirmed tier.

Consider replacing ink-muted with ink-soft (#4a4640) for muted-but-readable confirmed data, yielding approximately 4.3:1 contrast. loop_back_recommendations.reason: The existing behaves-006 (notification as continuation) should be extended with the adaptive frequency model from this run's behaves-004 (ambient-to-alert escalation).

The specific adaptation curve (frequent in month 1, ambient by month 3) needs to be integrated into the existing notification architecture so that agent-attributed notifications also follow the long-loop pattern.

loop_back_recommendations.reason: The active lease emotional architecture (feels-002, feels-003, feels-007) is the richest emotional contribution from this run. These elements should be cross-referenced against the existing guest-side active-lease emotions (guest-feels-001, guest-feels-005) to ensure the host and guest emotional arcs are compatible.
loop_back_recommendations.new_input: The host's emotional target during active lease is calm/offloaded vigilance. The guest's emotional target (from prior runs) is invisible system / ease. These are compatible but the enforcement feedback loop (host sees '$12 overage charged to guest on Feb 15') has a guest-side emotional impact that has not been designed for. The guest should not feel punished; the enforcement copy matters on both sides.
